caption.p:
Heterogeneity in host cell susceptibility reduces the total size of infected cells. (A) The final sizes (fractions) of infected cells at the end of infection [Average R(∞)], in a model using two identical layers of ER graphs. Results are average of 1,000 simulations. Colored lines show simulations assuming different levels of heterogeneities in host-cell susceptibility. The heterogeneity is characterized by a gamma distribution with the shape parameter k and scale parameters θ. Note, the lower the value of k, the more heterogeneous the host cell susceptibility. (B) The corresponding final sizes (fractions) of protected cells at the end of infection, P(∞), in simulations shown in (A). (C,D) Similar plots as in (A,B), respectively, except that the model assumes GR graphs in the network. The individual-cell effectiveness of the IFN signaling, R
F is set to seven. The average degree of the networks is set to 40, such that the value of R
I reaches 10 in simulations assuming k = 0.1 and θ = 20.
